Soren Brothers couldn‚Äôt shake off a recurring nightmare. 

Tornados and storms would lash against a bunker in which he was huddled, at the bottom of a stairwell. Outside, the scene was utter devastation: a climatic apocalypse, with the sky turning unearthly colours. Sometimes even the Grim Reaper would make a cameo.

Then Brothers would wake up, aware that he had spent another night in a climate-disaster dream. 

‚ÄúIt was regular enough that it was a part of my life,‚Äù he says.

The nightmares used to haunt Brothers more often when he was a PhD student in Berlin studying the interactions between climate change and lakes. 

They had become less frequent‚Äîreceding into memory, though still vivid‚Äîby the time he was announced, in November 2021, as the Royal Ontario Museum‚Äôs first curator of climate change.

It‚Äôs a highly visible platform: located in Toronto, the ROM is one of the most visited museums in Canada. 

Brothers is the face of the museum‚Äôs efforts to insert climate change into more of its collection and public events.

Yet, those expecting the museum to become an impassioned voice for greater climate action may initially be caught off guard.

Much of Brothers‚Äôs focus is on the positive and not just the calamitous‚Äîon initiatives that are working‚Äîeven if that‚Äôs not the tone some museum goers might expect.

Where‚Äôs the rallying cry, they may ask. It shows the challenge the ROM and other museums face in finding the words to explain the science to a broad audience and to push for action while not disappointing those wanting to hear a more vociferous outcry.

‚úçÔ∏è Guy Dixon

üì∑ The Walrus / Saty + Pratha / Royal Ontario Museum

There‚Äôs much excitement around AI in business but a lot of open questions too. How can AI transform your organization?

Craig Alleva is the Director of Customer Engineering for Google Cloud in Canada. In this episode of AI for Social Good, presented by @google Canada and produced by The Walrus Lab, he talks about the impact of #AI on Canadian organizations and how they‚Äôre applying it today.

On June 18, Canadian Sikh leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar was shot dead as he left the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia, at night. The forty-five-year-old was a prominent figure in the Sikh community in BC.

He had moved to Canada from the Indian state of Punjab in 1997 and worked as a plumber. At the time of his killing, he was president of the Sikh temple in Surrey.

Many in the Sikh community in Canada believed that the Indian government had something to do with the murder. 

Then, on September 18, following weeks of worsening ties with India, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau made it official.

‚ÄúOver the past number of weeks,‚Äù he said in Parliament, ‚ÄúCanadian security agencies have been actively pursuing credible allegations of a potential link between agents of the government of India and the killing of a Canadian citizen, Hardeep Singh Nijjar.‚Äù

India has denied Trudeau‚Äôs accusation, calling it ‚Äúabsurd,‚Äù and accuses Canada of being negligent in addressing its concerns about Sikh separatists. 

Trudeau‚Äôs explosive allegation reveals the widening rift between the two countries.

üîó Click the link in our bio to read the full review.

‚úçÔ∏è Sushant Singh
üì∑ The Canadian Press / Darryl Dyck

Women have long played supporting roles to great literary men.

Tolstoy‚Äôs wife, Sophia, edited his manuscripts; Milton had his daughters transcribe parts of Paradise Lost; V√©ra Nabokov did everything for Vladimir and also rescued Lolita from the trash more than once. V√©ra and Sophia set aside their own writerly ambitions to serve their husbands; Milton exploited and neglected his daughters. Tabitha King convinced Stephen to salvage Carrie, launching his career, later enduring his habit of playing ‚ÄúMambo No. 5‚Äù around the clock.

Many readers would likely argue the resulting works justify their sacrifices and suffering. 

But Daughter, Claudia Dey‚Äôs wry, furious new novel about a dysfunctional family in thrall to their fickle patriarch, tallies the costs borne by women to produce one great literary man.

üîó Click the link in our bio to read the full review.

‚úçÔ∏è Michelle Cyca (@michellecyca)
üì∑ The Walrus / Unsplash

Are bright, bold hues finally coming back?

The most popular colours of the past decade have been drab neutrals. But 2023‚Äôs colour of the year has finally given us something a little bit different: Raspberry Blush. A vivacious shade of reddish orange not far from that of nearly ripe fruit. At long last, a colour with a little bit of oomph.

Why, all of a sudden, do we have such vibrant colours popping onto our palettes‚Äîespecially at a time defined by the impending doom of the climate crisis, the war in Ukraine, and the crumbling economy?

What we‚Äôre experiencing now is likely a ripple effect of the pandemic, says Montaha Hidefi, a Guelph-based ‚Äúcolour archeologist‚Äù and colour-trend forecaster.

Two years of being cooped up, stuck staring at the same four walls, made us want to trade in our neutrals for explosions of colours reminiscent of adventure and excitement. Their re-emergence is a possible light at the end of what has been a difficult decade.

But don‚Äôt expect to wake up in a Wes Anderson‚Äìstyle world of colour next week. It can take months or seasons to see these trends reflected in our interiors, since they often start in fashion‚Äîthe most rapid of the trend cycles‚Äîand trickle outward from there.

‚ÄúIt seems like more people are ready to accept colour in their life, but it‚Äôs a step-by-step process,‚Äù says Hidefi. ‚ÄúMaybe it starts with a pillowcase. Then a sofa. And, eventually, someone might find the courage to paint an entire wall.‚Äù

üîó Click the link in our bio to read the full story.

‚úçÔ∏è Nicole Schmidt
üì∑ Celina Gallardo / iStock

Houses blown away. No power for weeks. Landmarks crumbling into the ocean. PEI survived its worst, most expensive storm with Fiona one year ago.

As dramatic footage of devastated coastal communities dominated national news in the days after the hurricane hit, debates began to rage about who should be accountable for securing Islanders and their properties from the impact of extreme weather.

The government had been announcing for days that a so-called storm of the century was likely to strike the Island. Why wasn‚Äôt the province more prepared?

Ahead of the one-year anniversary of Hurricane Fiona, Trevor Corkum spoke to Islanders about the disaster and the lessons they‚Äôve learned since.

üîó Click the link in our bio to read the full story.

‚úçÔ∏è Trevor Corkum
üé® Kat Frick Miller (@katfrickmiller)

As a society facing an increasing burden of cancer, costing an estimated $26 billion in 2021, how do we allocate resources? 

Should we continue spending $150,000, or more, a year to treat a patient with a drug that provides marginal benefits?

Christopher Booth, a medical oncologist and professor at Queen‚Äôs University in Kingston, Ontario, acknowledges that, in the past decade, we‚Äôve had some transformative medications. 

However, he says, these are exceptions floating in a sea of mediocre drugs that extend life for three months on average, often just weeks. 

There would be greater public health benefit if we instead put more into end-of-life care.

He says it‚Äôs easy to give a drug but almost impossible to find resources to let patients stay in their homes with good nursing, companionship, and good food.

‚ÄúWe completely fail patients near the end of life where we provide one thing but not the other,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúHow can we be okay with that?‚Äù

üîó Click the link in our bio to read the full story.

‚úçÔ∏è Ren√©e Pellerin
üé® Jeannie Phan (@jeanniephan)

It‚Äôs 2009. A Queen‚Äôs University student named Zoe sits on a bunk bed in a New York City hostel. She stares at her phone, unsure of what to do. It‚Äôs the nineteen-year-old‚Äôs first time in New York and her first time on a trip alone with her friends. She‚Äôs there for her spring break, with Dani‚Äîwhom she‚Äôs known since high school‚Äîand Fiona, a new addition to the friend group. Zoe and Dani have envisioned this trip for years. They imagined they would sightsee, play at being adults, and reconnect after months apart at their respective universities.

What they didn‚Äôt plan for were the complications a third person might introduce to their dynamic. From the day they arrive, a romance sparks between Fiona and Zoe. They‚Äôve mostly kept this from Dani, stealing away for moments alone and holding hands when her back is turned. But the night before Dani disappears, they hook up in their hostel with Dani in the room. Now Dani is gone, and she didn‚Äôt leave a note. As Zoe spirals, Fiona rolls her eyes.

‚ÄúYou have your phone,‚Äù Fiona says flatly. She recommends sending a text. 

Zoe puts her head in her hands and groans. ‚ÄúBut if I turn on roaming, won‚Äôt that cost a million dollars?‚Äù

Jillian (@jilliantamaki) and Mariko Tamaki (@marikotamaki), who wrote Roaming together, say the graphic novel‚Äôs title is partially a joke. While the word usually evokes the idea of exploration, for anyone travelling abroad, roaming comes with charges. The tension between these two things‚Äîfreedom and consequences‚Äîis central to the story. As these three young women explore an unknown city with a new-found sense of agency, they‚Äôre forced to learn that there are still boundaries to what they should and shouldn‚Äôt do‚Äîand pushing those boundaries comes with repercussions.

Mariko explains that nineteen is a potent and transitional age. ‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre on the lip of adulthood here,‚Äù she says. The push and pull between childhood and adulthood is part of what makes the dynamics in Roaming so complicated and messy.

üîó Click the link in our bio to read the full story.

‚úçÔ∏è Gabrielle Drolet (@gabrielle.drolet)
üì∑ The Walrus / Unsplash

"She holds a favourite serum up to the camera and squeezes a pea-sized drop onto the back of her terribly smooth hand. Rubs it into her skin in circular strokes, then sniffs it like she‚Äôs taking a hit. All the while enumerating, in a British accent, its many regenerating properties.

I don‚Äôt remember when the skinfluencer first showed up on my feed. What made me click on one of her YouTube videos, brought me to her glowing face smiling on my laptop screen. 

The titles of her videos, straightforward and unassuming, offer no clues to the grip they once held on my soul. I look at the thumbnails now‚Äî‚ÄúFave Fives: Cleansing Balms,‚Äù ‚ÄúAcid Toners Part One,‚Äù ‚ÄúHow I‚Äôm Dealing with My Pigmentation‚Äù‚Äîand I‚Äôm baffled. 

How did this content consume my life for two years? Become the stuff of obsession?"

Mona Awad, whose latest book, Rouge, was published by @penguincanada this month, unpacks her two-year skin care obsession and how it came to be. 

üîó Click the link in our bio to read the full story.

‚úçÔ∏è Mona Awad (@misss_read) 
üé® Melanie Lambrick (@melanielambrick)

When my son started school in the fall of 2015, I knew there would be a few challenges to overcome. 

Because he was attending a francophone program, the catchment zone was quite large, and he would have to start each day with a forty-five-minute bus ride across downtown Toronto.

My husband and I both worked full time, so my son would have to be in after-school care until one of us could get him, which would usually be around 6 p.m. Taking transit home took around forty-five minutes, which meant that we didn‚Äôt arrive at our apartment until close to 7 p.m. Add dinner and a bath into the mix, and that made for a long day.

Still, I wasn‚Äôt too worried. I thought it would all be fine‚Äîand, honestly, it was fine right up until the homework started.

The worksheets began trickling home during grade one, and by the next year, my son was getting thick weekly packets of them. 

The board policy was that children in his grade were supposed to receive around twenty minutes‚Äô worth of work per night, but in our house, the agony was never that brief.

One week in grade two, my son came home with seventeen pages of homework, printed front and back‚Äîthirty-four worksheets filled with math problems and language exercises. 

He worked on them every night, but by Sunday, he was only about three quarters of the way through.

He cried as he struggled to finish the homework. I cried as I emailed his teacher to tell her he hadn‚Äôt been able to finish it. 

We both felt like we‚Äôd failed.

We were told that the work wasn‚Äôt mandatory, but that put me in a difficult position. I felt like, as a parent, I should be supporting what his teachers wanted from him, not acting against it.

Besides, I believed that homework was necessary to set my son up for success. 

But it turns out that homework might not be as useful as we think, writes Anne Th√©riault.

üîó Click the link in our bio to read the full story.

‚úçÔ∏è Anne Th√©riault
üé® Doug Rodas (@doughism)

‚ÄúI was nervous to speak with Naomi Klein (@naomiaklein). For twenty-five years, she has shown an unfailing, unflagging ability to understand the invisible structures which scaffold our world and which skew it away from justice.

As a writer, speaker, thinker, and organizer, she has led a struggle against greed in its many forms, but her new book casts her gaze in a new direction: into the mirror.

Doppelganger is an examination of conservative populism, vaccine skepticism, ‚Äòwellness‚Äô flimflam, social media wish fulfillment, antisemitism, Zionism‚Äîand Klein‚Äôs ‚Äòbig-haired‚Äô mirror image, the commentator Naomi Wolf. It‚Äôs also a frank, and at times vulnerable, consideration of ego.

What would Klein observe in me, I wondered. What arrogance, artifice, or deception?

But when the time came and Klein picked up the phone, the conversation we had was warm, far reaching, and easy.‚Äù

As Naomi Klein‚Äôs latest book, Doppelganger, releases today, writer Sean Michaels (@swanmichaels) sat down with the renowned author and public figure to discuss the book, their own doppelgangers, and more.

üîó Read the full Q&A at the link in our bio.

‚úçÔ∏è Sean Michaels (@swanmichaels)
üì∑ The Walrus / Drica Veloso / Flickr

On Sunday, June 18, a tourist submersible carrying five people to the wreckage of the Titanic disappeared in the North Atlantic.

Five days later, a costly search‚Äîinvolving ships, planes, sonar, and a remotely operated vehicle (ROV)‚Äîrevealed that the Titan had imploded, scattering debris on the ocean floor and killing everyone on board.

The media‚Äôs focus centred on OceanGate Expeditions and its overly confident CEO, Stockton Rush, whose obsession with building a SpaceX for the ocean led to flouting of industry standards and regulations and a submersible built with off-the-shelf parts, including a now-notorious video game controller.

However, a curious Newfoundland connection evaded scrutiny.

üîó Click the link in our bio to read the full story.

‚úçÔ∏è Laura Trethewey
üì∑ Alamy

Transportation is one of the top three contributors to greenhouse gas emissions. üöó

This means commercial vehicles have the potential to make the most impact on climate change if deployed in a sustainable and efficient manner. 

Mike Branch is the Vice President of Data and Analytics at Geotab. In this episode of AI for Social Good, he discusses #AI and its ability to uncover inefficiencies to help boost decarbonization.

This podcast is presented by @google Canada and produced by The Walrus Lab.

üìöThe Walrus loves books. We love their transportive properties, how you can leave your body and enter their pages, how they dazzle us and expand our minds.

We channelled our love into this list of the top ten titles that we thought are poised to make a splash this fall.

The Bank of Canada announced today it would hold its interest rate steady at 5 percent.

Writer Colin Horgan argues the bank has little choice but to keep going according to its plan: either continue raising interest rates or at least hold them until it reaches its 2 percent inflation goal, should that ever happen.

Meanwhile, the political and social landscape has shifted. 

Under populist attack, facing a skeptical public, and without fiscal policy help, the bank, whatever credibility it might have had, is now facing intense scrutiny.

The bank is now at a crossroads. Canadians‚Äô faith in it has for decades rested on its mandate. 

But now that mandate looks to be at odds with the realities of the economy‚Äîand people‚Äôs lives.

What will it do?

üîó Click the link in our bio to read the full story.

‚úçÔ∏è Colin Horgan
üé® Min Gyo Chung (@mingyochung)

Not enough technological advancement is being applied to biodiversity loss.

Dr. Graham Taylor, a Professor and Canada Research Chair of Machine Learning at the School of Engineering at the @uofguelph, Research Director at the Vector Institute, and Canada CIFAR AI Chair, talks about the importance of protecting biological diversity, pushing boundaries with #AI, and driving future behaviours to improve life.

Listen to him speak on the AI for Social Good podcast, presented by @google Canada and produced by The Walrus Lab.

#biodiversity #biodiversityloss #ai #artificialintelligence #uofg #universityofguelph #biology #ecology #science #tech #technology #biologicaldiversity #future #innovation

When Indigenous filmmaker Alanis Obomsawin first got to Kanehsat√†:ke in July 1990, during what commonly became known as the Oka Crisis, she didn‚Äôt know how long she‚Äôd be there. She didn‚Äôt know that, over the following weeks, the RCMP would be called in or that the Canadian Armed Forces would send in more than 2,500 soldiers.

The standoff between the Kanien‚Äôkeh√°:ka and the army, the RCMP, and the provincial police lasted seventy-eight days, and Obomsawin would stay until the end.

She and her crew filmed clashes with the military; the army stopping food from reaching the land defenders; some locals hanging and burning an effigy of a warrior; a mob of Ch√¢teauguay residents stoning cars belonging to Kanien‚Äôkeh√°:ka, containing mostly women and children, with rocks the size of fists, windows shattering, glass shards lodged in skin, an elderly man hit in the chest, shirtless men cheering.

She interviewed the Kanien‚Äôkeh√°:ka women on the front lines of the standoff with the federal and provincial governments. She documented the protests held in solidarity with the Kanehsata‚Äôkehr√≥:non. And she filmed the army‚Äôs tanks pushing into Kanien‚Äôkeh√°:ka territory.

By early September, few journalists remained; the CBC had pulled its reporters from the scene, citing fears of further violence. 

Some believe Obomsawin‚Äôs continued presence with a camera likely tempered the army‚Äîthat things would have been worse if she weren‚Äôt there filming.
